artefact: Expenses and benefits: income tax paid on directors' behalf

artefact.alternative_title: Employers' tax and reporting for income tax paid on directors' behalf
artefact.overview: Tax and reporting rules for employers paying income tax on a directors' behalf

parts.title: Overview
parts.body:
As an employer paying income tax on behalf of company directors, you have certain National Insurance and reporting obligations.

What’s included

If you pay a company director without deducting tax under PAYE, and HMRC then recovers the unpaid tax from you, this counts as a benefit.

parts.title: What's exempt
parts.body:
You might not have to report or pay anything to HMRC if the director doesn’t have a ‘material interest’ in your company, and either of the following applies:

  • they’re a full-time working director
  • your company is a charity or not-for-profit organisation

In broad terms, a director has a material interest in a company if they (alone or together with associates) own or can control more than 5% of its ordinary share capital. This is explained in more detail in the technical guidance.

parts.title: What to report and pay
parts.body:
If the income tax you pay on a director’s behalf isn’t exempt, you’ll need to:

  • report on form P11D, section M
  • add the value of the benefit to the director’s earnings when deducting and paying Class 1 National Insurance (but not PAYE tax) through your payroll

parts.title: Work out the value
parts.body: Use the amount of tax recovered from you by HMRC, minus any amount paid back to you (‘made good’) by the director.

parts.title: Technical guidance
parts.body:
The following guides contain more detailed information:

  • PAYE tax not deducted from director’s earnings

  • Class 1 National Insurance contributions (NICs): earnings of employees and office holders

  • the meaning of ‘material interest’ in a company
